Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Structure and Dynamics of the Lithosphere-Asthenosphere System Beneath the Juan de Fuca Plate
Award.AbstractNarration: The PIs are funded to use surface and body wave tomographic techniques to examine the structure of the upper mantle beneath the Juan de Fuca Plate. OBS arrays associated with the Cascadia Initiative (CI) will be used in conjunction with land arrays to investigate the evolution of the plate?mantle system, from melt production and asthenospheric structure at the spreading center to plate deformation and small-scale convection at the subduction zone, as well as asthenospheric return flow from trench to ridge. Surface and body wave data will be combined in a joint inversion, followed by waveform modeling to refine tomographic images. An additional goal is to constrain the locations and mechanisms of moderate-sized earthquakes that occur before and during the experiment. The project will partner with education and outreach efforts associated with the CI, including mentoring community college students and contributing to the Seismometers@SchoolSites program for high school students. Post-doctoral scholars and graduate students will be trained. Project data will be incorporated into undergraduate coursework and research projects. The PIs will take advantage of the UO cloud computing facility for parts of the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to image the seismic velocity structure of the Juan de Fuca plate prior to its subduction beneath the northwestern United States.  The velocity structure provides information about the temperature of the subducting plate as well as the presence of water or melt (magma) within the mantle.  The temperature and hydration of the plate may affect the generation of large earthquakes beneath the coast of Washington, Oregon and northern California.  Data for the project consists of seismograms recorded in the Cascadia Initiative by arrays of ocean-bottom seismometers over a four-year period.

 

We used the propagation of Rayleigh waves across the arrays to measure the velocities.  These seismic surface waves were generated by distant earthquakes.  In order to improve the signal-to-noise ratios, we improved a technique to remove the effects of ocean bottom currents on the seismometers as well as removing the effects of long-period water waves whose pressure effects displace the seafloor slightly, obscuring the earthquake-induced motions.  To study the deep structure, it also is important to have good constraints on the sediments, so we developed a new technique for measuring shear velocity in the sediments and applied it at all the ocean-bottom seismometer sites.

 

To produce a shear velocity model of the mantle beneath the Juan de Fuca plate, we began by constructing a starting model that contained all available information about water depth, sediment velocity and thickness, crustal structure and age of the seafloor.  We predicted velocity in the mantle based on the age of the seafloor and a conductive cooling model of the oceanic lithosphere (plate).  We then found what corrections to the starting model were required to satisfy the Rayleigh wave observations.  The final model at a depth of 25 km and the simpler starting model are shown in the attached figure.  We found that, unlike the predictions in the starting model, the velocities in the vicinity of the Juan de Fuca spreading ridge were asymmetric about the ridge, with the slowest velocities west of the ridge axis.  There is a rapid increase in velocities to the east of the axis ending in much higher velocities in the interior of the plate than expected.  This pattern is best explained by a dynamic component of flow in the mantle in which there is buoyant upwelling west of the ridge axis, probably associated with the hotspot that forms Axial seamount and the Cobb-Eickelberg seamount chain.  The buoyant, convective upwelling is balanced by downwelling beneath the interior of the plate, leading to freezing of any melt, producing the unexpectedly high velocities.

 

We also found velocity anomalies beneath the continental margin that may be caused by hydrothermal alteration of the mantle just before subduction.  The hydrothermal alteration may affect the subduction process, including the generation of mega-earthquakes.  There is a correlation between the location of the anomalies and the changing characteristics of episodic tremor and slip in the subduction zone. 

 

There are 3 types of broader impacts of this study.  First, understanding the structure of the subducting plate may help to understand the potential for large earthquakes along different parts of the Cascadia subduction zone.  Second, the new techniques we developed for noise removal and inferring sediment structure will be of general use for other seismologists using ocean-bottom instrumentation.  Third, this study contributed directly to the training and development of scientists through the involvement of an undergraduate, a graduate student and two post-doctoral students in the research.  The grad student and one of the post-docs participated in research cruises, getting their first exposure to oceanographic techniques.
